bibl.title: Letter from L.H. Baekland to the Editor of the New York Times, 1924

div1.p: Baekland refers to the recent publication of a letter and Howard's response regarding Kean's role. He includes a direct quote from Howard's letter.

div1.head: Letter from L.H. Baekland to the Editor of the New York Times, 1924
div1.opener:
FROM L. O. HOWARD
OR LUCY HOWARD
(COPY)
no date given
Editor of New York Times
New York City
Subject: Mosquitoes & Yellow Fever
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
Last week while in Washington, I called the attention
of Dr. L. O. Howard, Chief of the Bureau of Entomology, to a letter
which recently appeared in your paper on the subject of the elimina-
tion of the mosquito in Cuba.

Since then, I received a letter from Dr. Howard. He
writes as follows:

“I sent an assistant to the Congressional Library to look up the files,
and she found the article in the Times for Sunday, April 27th. I have
read it with interest, and especially note that it was written by
Colonel J. R. Kean, of the Medical Corps of the, U. S. Army. As it
happens, I know Colonel Kean, and as it happens also he very modestly
does not mention his own part in the clearing up of Havana. The work
that was done under the General Order No. 6 of General Leonard Wood,
issued on December 21, 1900, giving minute instructions as to the war-
fare against mosquitoes based upon my bulletin published a year before,
was done by Colonel Kean. Major Gorgas, on the other hand, did not
take up this antimosquito work until February 15, 1901, nearly three
months after Colonel Kean had been doing it.”
div1.closer:
Respectfully yours, (Signature) L. H. Baekeland,
President. LHB:GSB
